comments.commentBody: Water is not just a local resource, and saying so is about as logical as saying air is a local resource. Waste is waste. There is a definite possiblity that centuries from now overpopulated and overpolluted countries will wage war for water with the same zeal they wage war for oil today.

I didn't have much fun with this puzzle, but part of that's just because for me, the title gave away the theme. I got LETTHETIMESROLL on my first go-round, which made me smile--that was my favorite along with YOUREAMANCHARLIEBROWN (I am Jewish after all).

I loved seeing George COSTANZA make its way into the grid, as well as Joan CUSACK and DAS BOOT. I also enjoyed the clues for SRI, SWAN, AGENDA, and GABFEST.

What I couldn't stand were all the foreign language gimmes, and some that I didn't know at all. I understand a couple of Spanish/French 101 words, but in one single grid there should not be ALLE, DIA, PORC, ARIGATO, ONZE, ILS, NIE, and others clued differently like SRI and ELLE.

Also, I didn't like AWEATHER, DULLEA I'd never heard of, and the worst: ULLA.
This puzzle was a DNF because of that intersection.

I think this puzzle could've been better, but I did enjoy the theme, so thanks.

I must say this puzzle is one of life's memorable experiences.  We wait all day and I post comments almost hourly like Burma Shave signs along the country road in the 1940s leading up to the name of the shaving cream.  At the end of the day I don't see Burma Shave.  I don't even see technical problems.  I just see Joe painting that barn a bright red color for everyone to see beyond that Burma Shave sign.  Oh well, at least the drive through the Blue Ridge Mountains and into Bardstown Kentucky for that Virginia country ham and eggs with raisin toast made for an interesting journey.

These increases would raise close to a billion dollars a year in new revenue for the Port Authority. Fine, if it is all used for transit. Not so fine if the money will simply be split between the governors of the two states (adding to money that is already split with the governors) for non-transit purposes. When I delved into the PA budget 20 years ago, I found that the GW bridge was the only real moneymaker the PA had, of any kind. It subsidized a bit of mass transit, the WTC, the airports, and all manner of non-transit projects. One of those projects was at Columbia University, where I was  a full-time faculty member. The PA, using its leverage, tried to get me fired (fortunately Columbia, at least at the time, behaved ethically). My study appeared in a refereed journal (Business and Society Review) and in a newspaper article under my byline. The facts disclosed were never challenged in any way... and never covered by the city's newspaper of record.

And finally, to Evan and all those other commentors bemoaning the abuse and lack of precision of terms like "local" while simultaneously never considering the abuse and lack of precision of terms like "hipster," "artist" or "bohemian," here is Suleiman Osman, in his The Invention of Brownstone Brooklyn, pp.11-12: "In 1971, a local civic group conducted a survey of 326 new brownstone owners in Brooklyn and Manhattan. The respondents were overwhelmingly whiter, wealthier, and more educated than the average New York resident.Whereas 30 percent of New Yorkers were nonwhite, brownstone renovators were 99 percent white. While only 17 percent of New Yorkers earned more than $10,000, 98.3 percent of respondents had higher incomes. But more than financial capital, what distinguished Brooklyn's new brownstone middle class was its cultural and social capital. In a city where just over 50 percent of people twenty-five or older were high school graduates, 99.9 percent of respondents had high school diplomas, and a striking 60 percent had attended graduate school. Surprisingly, historians have not paid much attention to this powerful urban constituency."

If the locals can't use the word "local" to appeal to vestigial rights over property, neither can you use either the word or the romance "art" or "hip" to appeal to a vestigial right to seize property.

In Canada right now with my iPhone data roaming off, using Talkatone (app available from App store), which leverages Google Voice phone number to make Skype-like wifi calls for free.  Outgoing calls can also be made by 5c per minute phone card available at Costco or CVS to call to 800 number accessible by room phone.  Hotel wifi supports Internet email and browsing ... total communications cost for weekend:  pennies.  A little Google searching and some prep work does it.

Dennis (comment 166) - you have good points but we should make a distinction here. There are self sufficient communities like Williamsburg or Greenpoint that would've done just fine without an influx of newcomers, and were in fact displaced. Regarding those communities, it's pretty clear there were winners and losers.

However, Hudson, Beacon and Kingston have not been self sufficient for decades; they were crumbling. They needed revenue and new businesses, and the newcomers are bringing that. Case in point: I drove by Basilica in Hudson tonight, the art space featured in the video that accompanies this article. It was an abandoned, dilapidated eyesore on the riverfront, for years. Tonight, there were artists performing inside and people congregating outside.

Life was hollowed out by the dismantling of the old economy, and remained void for decades. New life has moved in. If you pour water into an empty bucket, you didn't "displace" the water that was poured out thirty years ago.

Continuing, "It is precisely why, previously, I have suggested a University be established in Williamsburg that supplies locals with that college experience and thus extinguish the distinction between them, and the agents of gentrification who have passed off, for too long, as "artists", but only as apologia for gentrification, and as tools for Real Estate."

Indeed, Bloomberg has recently offered $100 million and free Real Estate for an applied science university in New York City. Carnegie-Mellon is making application for University at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. If Beacon had University, and locals were embedded in that University either through jobs or housing, you would both dispel the economic malaise Beacon is suffering, and the need for gentrification so that "art" can pretend to exist.

"The protesters were set off by the shooting of Mark Duggan, 29, a local man with four children who was allegedly killed by the police in a shootout involving several officers in North London on Thursday, The Sun reports."

In years past, British police did not carry guns and gun ownership was banned for most people there. I guess the NRA has influence in Britain just like in the U.S.
No. Let's not start any hysteria.

It's a reasonable statement to say that these protesters live in one of the worlds freest democracies. There is no justification for the destruction and mayhem they have caused. There are much better ways to resolve their issues.
The smell of burning tires and diesel fumes hung thick in humid night air.
Not London Calling but London's Burning by the Clash.
We're tired of the police abusing their rights. The world over. The United States included.
There is nothing new under the sun.

Right. Protest by breaking into stores.

Just thieves waiting for any excuse to steal something.

When our poor and dispossessed march into the wealthy communities, our police will have no hesitation in firing their weapons to protect the chosen few. That is consistent with our heavily armed Capitol Hill where there are worries about the nature of the PEOPLE and a determination to keep them docile.

And it is a difference between us and the Brits.
Labour's Legacy.

Totally disgusting behaviour, these hooligans should all be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law possible. There is no room for this type of action in civilized British society, simply shameful.
There is a lot of injustice. And anger at "austerity", look into it more to understand and empathize and engage....
And so it begins...
I am correct in thinking these 'police' don't carry firearms? Of course they are scared. In the U.S. they would not even be called police if they were not packing. This is what you get.
This is a job for the good Reverend.

This sort of behavior occurred in cities in the United States for years during the 1960s. The result was that the neighborhoods where the police were shot at for doing their job became more dangerous than ever, businesses and jobs disappeared, the fires (literal fires) were no longer put out, and people stayed destitute for generations if they lived long enough. Drugs and gangs claimed more of the people living in those neighborhoods than jobs and flight to a better life.

The police need to be able to do their job without false accusations of racism and if they don't have the support of the people they're protecting, then those neighborhoods will become a hell on earth as a consequence. Look at Newark New Jersey or Detroit to see what that looks like; London is a wonderful city; lets hope it doesn't continue down that road.
You can't alway sweep garbage under the rug. It eventually composts, ferments and ignites.
